block.p: India and Pakistan Held Secret Talks, Officials Say Pakistan's decision to end state support for Islamic militants in Kashmir was reached after eight months of secret negotiations between Indian and Pakistani officials, and cemented after one of the recent attacks on the Pakistani president, according to officials in Islamabad.

India and Pakistan Held Secret Talks, Officials Say Pakistan's decision to end state support for Islamic militants in Kashmir was reached after eight months of secret negotiations between Indian and Pakistani officials, and cemented after one of the recent attacks on the Pakistani president, according to officials in Islamabad.

Iraqi Weapons Team Withdrawn The Bush administration has withdrawn the military team that was scouring Iraq for military equipment. The step was described by some as a sign that the caches of weapons cited as a reason for going to war will not be found.
Insurgents in Iraq fired mortar rounds at an American military camp, wounding 35 soldiers in an area used for living quarters. They were given first aid and evacuated for medical treatment.
Frequent breakdowns in supplies of fuel and electricity, especially in Baghdad, are defying attempts by both Iraqis and foreign occupiers to stitch together something resembling normalcy.

Israeli-Libyan Secret Meetings Israeli and Libyan officials held a secret meeting in December and discussed the possibility of ties between the longstanding enemies. Officials warned that the contacts are tentative and the Libyan Foreign Ministry denied meeting at all.

Drugs Program Was Halted A United States program to shoot down airplanes in Latin America suspected of ferrying drugs was suspended this fall for a second time, after the Colombian military forced down a plane and then strafed it even though American monitoring personnel had not give their authorization.
U.S. Suspends Cuba Talks The Bush administration has suspended immigration talks with Cuba, saying that Havana has repeatedly refused to discuss certain technical and political issues.

Illegal-Immigrant Plan By Bush Draws Criticism President Bush urged Congress to pass his plan to give undocumented workers in the United States temporary legal status. But his proposal drew criticism from some groups involved in the issue for not going far enough to help immigrants and from others for rewarding people who had come into the country illegally.

President Adds $47 Million President Bush's campaign said it took in $47 million in the last three months of 2003, bringing his yearly total to $130.8 million and extending his financial edge over the Democrats seeking to challenge him.
Less Dean, Less of the Time Howard Dean's campaign has begun to limit his availability to the news media, and the candidate is watching his words after several recent statements unleashed criticism.
Daschle Urges Beef Labeling Tom Daschle, the Senate Democratic leader, called for the Bush administration to require supermarket meat to carry country-of-origin labels immediately.

Declaring Citizens Enemies The Bush administration reasserted its broad authority to declare American citizens to be enemy combatants, and it suggested that the Supreme Court consider two prominent cases at the same time.

Heart Drug Beats Usual Choice People with a hard-to-treat type of cardiac arrest are three times as likely to survive if they are given a drug called vasopressin than if they receive the standard emergency treatment, adrenaline.
Global Warming and Extinctions An international group of 19 scientists has concluded that a warming climate will prompt widespread extinctions this century.

Governor of Connecticut Pleads to Keep His Job Gov. John G. Rowland apologized in a televised speech for lying, pleaded to keep his job in the face of mounting ethical scandals and asked for a chance to redeem himself.
Property Tax Rebate Plan Mayor Bloomberg plans to give back the 18.5 percent property tax increase instituted more than a year ago in a one-time rebate.
Debating Gay Rights Bill A measure that would establish legal recognition for same-sex couples over age 62 is expected to undergo intense debate today in the New Jersey State Senate.

Former Nurse Offers Deal A nurse who has claimed he killed more than 30 patients has offered to help determine which ones he deliberately injected with fatal amounts of medication. It appears unlikely that prosecutors will agree to the deal, which would allow him to avoid the death penalty.
Redskins Coach Returns Joe Gibbs, 63, came out of retirement Wednesday to coach the Washington Redskins.
Suits Over Co-op Flaws About 35 co-op and condominium boards, most of them in New York City, are seeking damages for physical problems in their buildings.

Enron Guilty Plea Expected Andrew S. Fastow, the former chief financial officer of Enron, has tentatively agreed to plead guilty to fraud charges and has provided evidence for criminal charges expected to be brought against another former high-ranking executive, people involved in the case said.

U.S. Debt Risks Instability The United States is running up a foreign debt of such record-breaking proportions that it threatens the financial stability of the global economy, according to report released by the International Monetary Fund.

Parmalat Inquiry Widens Italian prosecutors are widening their investigation of Parmalat to include Italian and foreign banks, which they suspect helped Parmalat's senior officials spread false information about the company.
